page.title: 14Curdridge Post Office&Stores
page.content: The Curdridge Post Office and Village Stores was built in 1900 when it was the front room of a house. The present Postmistress has lived there since 1967 and has made 3 extensions. She receives money from the Head Postmaster in Southampton to pay out benefits. Each week she has to pay Child Allowance, Old Age Pension, and she pays Unemployment Benefit once a fortnight. She sells stamps (postage stamps, first day covers, T.V. and telephone saving stamps) and Postal Orders. The Postmistress also runs the only Village Store. She buys most of her stock from Nurdin and Peacock at Eastleigh. She has to price the stock and put it on the shelves. She also has to keep accounts and work out VAT and TAX. She enjoys her life and would not wish to leave Curdridge.
